This may be the most important statistical test yet ... theres some assumptions to it, mainly on the standard deviation of your sample and the underlying true distribution (you don't usually know that one for sure). However, there is even a version of this test, that tries to throw out that assumption ... it's not quite perfect, but it's actually pretty good. It#s called Welch t-Test.
You can use this concept to compare whatever two groups ... specifically their mean values.

Oh and just to mention it: If you REALLY care about the assumtions on distribution, there's so called non-parametric tests. Those don't care about that assumption. The draw back is that they are usually less precise.

If you want to compare more than 2 groups there's also tests for that as well. You could also just use this one repeatedly, although you would have to adjust the critical value because of the fact that the random noise will give you more false positives than expected if you repeat it. Usually you would do that adjusting by something like the so called Bonferroni correction. It's rather simple ... Basically if your criteria would normally be to say "theres a difference if my measurement falls into the upper or lower 5%" and you do 10 times the number of tests, you would instead go like "oh ... better make that not 5% but 0.5%"

It's a pretty mighty test.

Nice work humanizing Gosset and his work on t distribution. Unfortunately, the exposition on how the t distribution arise from small sample is at least a little bit misleading.

To be clear, if you take many small samples (say samples of 5) from a normally distributed population (which is a formal requirement for using t distribution), calculate the sample mean for each, and plot the resulting histogram, you WILL GET A NORMAL DISTRIBUTION. In modern times this can be quite readily verified by running some simulation in your favorite statistical program.

The issue of this normal distribution is that you CANNOT MAKE any MEANINGFUL INFERENCE based on it, if you have only a SINGLE small sample. The reason is that any meaningful inference (e.g., the probability that the true mean is off from the sample mean by such and such value) based on this distribution depends on the TRUE standard deviation (or equivalently the variance) of the population, which you have no access to.

So instead you APPROXIMATE the true standard deviation by the SAMPLE STANDARD DEVIATION. This approximation, and the uncertainty it introduces, is the sole reasoning you get the t distribution. More mathematically, while (sample mean - true mean) is normally distributed, (sample mean - true mean) / (sample standard deviation) is t distributed. The upside, however, is that this t distribution does not depend on the true standard deviation and thus can be used to make inference, e.g., of the type mentioned above.
I have actually used t-distribution in a software project for a water quality lab for small sampling. It is cool to hear this channel discussing the statistics being used.

Beer is not made by "mix[ing] some barley or other grain with flavored water". You mash the malted grains to convert starch to sugar and extract it, then you combine this (what you could call "grain-flavored water") with hops to add the hop flavor and aroma. I'm leaving out a ton of details, but that's the basic process. The hop flavor is not added to the water before the grain is, in any recipe I've seen.

30 years previously, 1876, Jacob Lüroth already published his work about the t-distribution and called it "a-posteriori distribution". But because his work was purely academical and without any direct application (he just tried to calculate the Bayesian interval), William Sealy Gosset had to reinvent it without knowing Lüroth's work.

I always say, "Praise Be to Beer" when I teach the t-test. I had high hopes this would be a better way to tell the story of Gosset and the t-test. Unfortunately, the description of the issues with small samples was terribly incorrect. The issues described by the presenter are about how the sample is collected, how representative the sample is of the population. But, that's not the problem Gosset was trying to solve. Gosset was trying to solve the problem of not having knowledge of the variability of the population (of sugars in beers, or whatever else might be measured) either because it is impossible to actually know, or too difficult to get, a proper census of the population. Gosset's big insight was that the small samples themselves provided a rough estimate of the variability that existed in the population. But, given the sample was small, these estimates would vary a good bit, too. Therefore, Gosset developed a way to take into account the uncertainty that came from using small sample's variance (& standard deviation) to estimate population's variance (& standard deviation). That is what lead to the definition of the t-distribution and the t-test (which was the same as the long-known z-test substituting the estimate of standard deviation for the presumably known standard deviation of the population). In essence, to be confident of a difference we are observing between two means can be trusted to tell us something about the population we need to see a bigger difference in comparison to the observed variation compared to the degree of difference we might see for a z-test.

Not entirely correct: Guinness had a long history of hiring Oxbridge graduates for positions like this already. Part of the reason he had to use the name "Student" was because Guinness employees published a lot and on several occasions had leaked trade secrets to competitors by accident via published research. That's why Guinness had a prohibition against employees publishing anything mentioned (a) their surname, (b) Guinness, or (c) anything vaguely related to the company, so no mention of beer or brewing, to anything about grain related to brewing or distilling.
